docs.lead_paragraph: The usual post-holiday drop in the nation's blood supply has been made worse because of severe winter storms, prompting the American Red Cross to make an urgent call for donors. Urgently needed is Type O blood, the universal blood type that can be safely transfused into most people in an emergency. ''The severe winter weather has forced the cancellation of blood drives and limited our ability to collect blood,'' said Elizabeth Dole, president of the Red Cross.

headline.main: Bad Weather Worsens Shortage in Nation's Blood Supply

docs.lead_paragraph: It is early on a winter morning at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary here, and Dr. Ralph Metson is executing what has been until now one of the most demanding, difficult and dangerous procedures in the treatment of sinus disease. With a variety of drill bits, he bores into bone blocking the frontal sinus, separated from the brain by one of the thinnest bones in the body. One infinitesimally small slip by Dr. Metson could result in leaked spinal fluid, impaired vision or lost sense of smell for the 58-year-old patient.

headline.main: Sinus Surgery at Edge of the Brain Gets Safer

docs.lead_paragraph: Women in medicine have made phenomenal strides over the past 30 years. They are everywhere, in every specialty, and they account for half of all medical students; women even play doctors on television -- with their trusty husky male nurses, of course. Yet for all the progress, female physicians still suffer from what might be called stipendicitis: an acute failure of the wallet to perform as expected. According to the latest Physician Compensation and Production survey, the average incomes of female doctors continue to lag behind those of their male counterparts, not just by a few thousand dollars, but by tens of thousands, and in some specialties by more than $100,000 a year. And, as the accompanying chart, published in Physicians Weekly, demonstrates, the gap lately has widened for a number of specialties, rather than diminished.

docs.lead_paragraph: Should drug companies use celebrities, like the Baltimore Orioles' Cal Ripken, in advertisements for prescription drugs? ALISHA BERGER Until recently, pharmaceutical companies focused advertising efforts on prescribing doctors, inundating them with vast numbers of ''throw-away journals'' that invariably bypassed their targets and ended up in the trash. More recently, pharmaceutical companies have discovered that they achieve greater success pitching products directly to the public. Recently, there has been an explosion of several excellent drugs to treat depression, migraine headaches, allergies, hypertension and stomach disorders. In each class of these drugs, several more or less equivalent versions have been introduced. The drugs are generally safe and effective. Since the drugs are inherently good, there is no reason celebrities should not be hired to promote a product, since the intent is simply to raise market share. There is some societal good in having celebrities pitch products because more patients with hypertension or depression may present themselves for treatments. Bringing more patients into the medical fold is certainly good for my business.

docs.lead_paragraph: When my twin sons were born 29 years ago, fetal monitoring was not a routine part of labor and delivery, and there was no way to be certain the babies were doing O.K. while my uterus tried in vain to expel them. So when the doctor announced after many anxious hours of unproductive labor that he was going to have to deliver them by Caesarean, my response was, ''I don't care if I cough them up as long as they're alive and healthy.''

headline.main: A Saner Approach On Caesarean Issue

docs.lead_paragraph: A recent study indicates that adding stretching to a weight-training routine may actually improve strength, in addition to increasing flexibility. The study, conducted by Dr. Wayne Westcott, director of fitness research at the South Shore Y.M.C.A. in Braintree, Mass., followed 53 participants in a 10-week strength-training program. Each subject worked out on 13 standard weight-training machines. After each exercise, one group stretched the muscles just used before moving to the next machine. A second group moved from machine to machine, then followed with a separate session of six stretching exercises. The third group did no flexibility exercises.

headline.main: Stretches Make the Arms Grow Stronger

docs.lead_paragraph: Teen-agers, traditional wisdom holds, are sullen, prickly creatures, prone to mood swings and sudden outbursts of temper. But new research suggests that for some adolescents depression -- in particular, symptoms like lack of enjoyment in everyday activities or frequent thoughts about death -- signals an increased risk of serious depression in adulthood.

docs.lead_paragraph: Statistics show that falls among older adults -- often the cause of serious injury -- can be prevented in many cases with a program of exercises specifically geared toward improving balance and posture. The Journal of the American Geriatric Society reports that one-third of people over 65 fall at least once a year, many of them incurring injuries like broken hips that may never properly mend. Many experts believe that age-related falls are caused in part by a reduced sense of balance and a loss of ability to judge body placement.

docs.lead_paragraph: In mythology, fire-breathing monsters with lions' heads, goats' bodies and serpents' tails are well-known chimeras. In humans, chimeras form when cells from two people live side by side in one person, during and after such diverse events as pregnancy, organ transplantation and blood transfusion.

headline.main: Keeping Harmony in the Marriage of Cells
